results.title: The Game is up!
results.creator_credit: Meg Labrum, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and John Tutty
results.brief_description: The National Film and Sound Archive has drawn on its unique film collection in a selection of vintage newsreels, home movies, advertisements and feature film footage looking at women’s contribution to Australia’s sporting culture. The video is accompanied by an excellent teacher resource guide. Presented in chronological order some of the highlights include Annette Kellerman’s underwater ballet in 1914, Vera James in the classic film of 1921, ‘A Girl of the bush’, The Australian Women’s Cricket team of 1937 and of course the golden girls of the Melbourne Olympics of 1956.

results.title: The Game
results.brief_description: An animated film which deals with the problem of how to cope with playing by the rules and with those sho do not abide by the rules. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: John Kemeny, ONF | NFB and George Kaczender
results.brief_description: This is the boy-meets-girl game, but played without rules and at a time when the boy must prove himself in the chase. It is about the much-discussed sexual behavior of teenagers and shows that often the game starts with a challenge to his masculine ego from the boy’s peer group. Few adults are seen or heard from, nor does the film take sides in this game. A dramatisation.

results.title: The Gamblers
results.brief_description: Refers to bulldozing of earth banks, use of brakes, lowering of blades, adjustment of the machine while in operation, fraying of cables, starting, difficulties with children and so on when using earthmoving equipment. An excellent film for large contracting firms and for others using earthmoving plant.

results.title: The Gambler Dostoevsky
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Risk”.
A play based on Dostoevsky’s novel “The Gambler”. Dostoevsky lived his life on the edge of disaster, financial, political and emotional, and the story is about his gambling and about his loving. Dostoevsky’s widow, Anna, recalls her relationship with this complicated man.

results.title: The Gambia greets the Queen
results.brief_description: The West African tour of HM Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh in 1961. The welcome in the capital city of Bathurst, a meeting with the assembled chiefs of the Protectorate, and a journey by launch up the great Gambia River. A colorful impression of Gambia and its people.

results.title: The Gadfly
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett, Film Australia and Lewis Fitz-Gerald
results.brief_description: Starring John Derum, this is a dramatised documentary about Francis James, one of Australia’s most intriguing post WWII figures. He was imprisoned in China for three years in 1969 as a spy. His release was eventually secured with the help of his old school friend, Gough Whitlam. There is still some doubt as to why he was incarcerated in China. It may be he was a spy. Or perhaps he was merely trying to ressurect a shattered journalistic reputation after published photographs he claimed were Chinese misssile sites proved to be fake. This is the story of a journalist, theologina, prankster and Walter Mitty character, a man who dressed in a cape, wore a black broad brimmed hat, wrote copy for a newspaper out of the back of an old Rolls Royce, a man who told wild exaggerated stories and quoted Keats and Plato, a man from another age.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Bennett, Film Australia and Lewis Fitz-Gerald

results.title: The Future that Was
results.creator_credit: Lorna Pegram, David Richardson, RM Productions, Time-Life Films and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
Part 8 of an 8-part series which presents a social history of the impact and development of the visual arts in the 20th century. In this episode, art critic, Robert Hughes discusses the future of modern art. He examines how modern art has gradually lost its sense of newness and possibility, and how the avant-garde has become a dying form. The program explores the influences museums, investment and media have had on the general public’s response to modern art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lorna Pegram, David Richardson, RM Productions, Time-Life Films and BBC-TV

results.title: The Future of one million Africans
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A study of conditions in Bechuanaland, Basutoland, and Swaziland, the British protectorates on the borders of South Africa. The resources and products of each territory are looked at in turn. The contrast between modern ways of living and the old tribal traditions. How the problem of drought, with consequent soil erosion and deterioration is being tackled everywhere by engineering, agricultural and pastoral development. Improvements in medicine and education. How many of the natives leave the protectorates for short period to earn money in South African mines. Explains and discusses the political setup; how the High Commissioner worked with the help of Residential Commissioners and native Advisory Councils. Brief history of South African relations with the protectorates.
